Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Data Integration to Enable Cancer Research

Division.LongName: Div Of Molecular and Cellular Bioscience

Award.AbstractNarration:
Datasets of all types are being generated at a fast pace. A central challenge for life science researchers is sharing, integrating, and analyzing disparate data types to discover fundamental biological principles. This project seeks to address that challenge by leveraging the tools and cyberinfrastructure developed through the NSF BIO-funded CyVerse project (CyVerse.org; DBI-12565383) to develop and test novel computational solutions that will allow the vast imaging data housed in the Cancer Imaging Archive to be shared and analyzed with other relevant data types. The results of this work should provide new, much-needed tools for the cancer research community. In addition, the outcomes should serve as the basis for developing new solutions for integrating data types for the broader biomedical and basic research communities.

Data-driven discovery, especially in the field of cancer research, is hampered by poor interoperability across data storage platforms and limited access to tools for computational integration of large, heterogeneous datasets. To address these limitations, two pilot projects will be conducted. The first will integrate TCIA image data with CyVerse's image management and analysis capabilities, developing a proof-of-concept model for how researchers can rapid manage and analyze high-quality cancer image data. The second pilot will enable cancer researchers at University of Arizona Cancer Center and elsewhere to aggregate their public and private cancer image data using CyVerse's capabilities and to integrate image and genomic data via a custom user interface. Together, the results of these pilots will provide researchers with the computational systems and technology needed to more rapidly manage, analyze, and disseminate their work.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The objectives of this project were to enhance the ability of cancer researchers to access and use images within the National Cancer Institute’s Cancer Imaging Archive (TCIA), and to combine TCIA data with other kinds of cancer related information. TCIA provides a central repository for curated high-resolution cancer images.  One limitation is the inability to easily combine images and associated information across the different TCIA datasets and to combine this image information with other types of cancer related information, including genomic data.  For this project, the entire TCIA image archive was incorporated into the National Science Foundation supported CyVerse cyberinfrastructure platform for data management and analysis.  CyVerse is freely available to anyone and has more than 70,000 user accounts. Incorporating TCIA images and related metadata into CyVerse has made them broadly available to researchers and also for analysis in CyVerse’s image analysis platform called BisQue. The Cancer Genome Atlas (TCGA) houses valuable genomics related cancer data, however this data is not connected to the TCIA imaging archive. TCGA data was therefore brought into CyVerse and connected to the TCIA imaging archive.  Finally, a stand alone portal was developed to facilitate viewing, querying and retrieval of datasets and image types, and automated updating of data from TCIA and TGCA.  This resource expands the utility of The Cancer Imaging Archive by making the dataset more broadly available on a widely use cyberinfrastructure platform and by combining cancer related imaging and genomic data.
